Material used.Description: For kinase assays, SF - TAP tagged LRRK2 variants were expressed in HEK293 cells. HEK293 cells were transfected with 4 μg plasmid DNA/14 cm culture dish using Effectene. Cells were lysed 48 h post - transfection. The MalE - fusion proteins were expressed in BL21 (DE3) following standard protocols. HEK293 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum at 37°C and 5% CO2.

Readout description.Result Description: LRRK2 G2019S is able to phosphorylate recombinant MKK3 and MKK6 in vitro. LRRK2 G2019S was also able to phosphorylate MKK4 and MKK7. The kinase dead variant of LRRK2, LRRK2 K1906M, served as a negative control and showed no MKK3/6 phosphorylation. The tested kinase domain mutants LRRK2 G2019S and LRRK2 I2020T exert increased kinase activity towards MKK6. LRRK2 G2019S shows about 3 - 4 - fold increase in kinase activity compared with wild - type LRRK2, LRRK2 I2020T shows only a slight, but significant, increase of about 1.5 - fold of wild - type activity. The Roc - domain mutant LRRK2 R1441C showed no significant alteration in its kinase activity. MKK4 and MKK7 are phosphorylated by LRRK2 at their canonical activation residues, while MKK6 is not phosphorylated at these residues. LRRK2 phosphorylates MKK6 at its N - terminal lobe.

Basic negative control.Description: The kinase dead variant of LRRK2, LRRK2 K1906M, served as a negative control and showed no MKK3/6 phosphorylation. The MalE - fusion tag alone was used as negative control in in vitro kinase assays. The antibody's specificity was controlled by the MKK7 mutant K149A+S271A/T275A lacking these residues as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: For the comparison of different LRRK2 mutants, at least four independent data points were used for each mutant and differences in phosphorylation levels were probed for statistical significance by analysis of variance (ANOVA). Pair - wise comparison was performed by Tukey's post - hoc test.

Material used.Description: Proteins separated on Nupage 4 - 12% gradient gels (Invitrogen) were blotted onto low fluorescent polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membranes (GE - Healthcare). Equal loading of used substrate proteins was confirmed by Ponceau staining of the membranes. LRRK2 levels were determined by probing the blots with monoclonal rat anti LRRK2 antibodies. Phosphorylation of MKK4, MKK6 and MKK7 at their canonical phosphorylation sites was tested by probing the blots with phosphospecific polyclonal antibodies.

Readout description.Result Description: Western blot analysis using a polyclonal MKK7 antibody that recognises phosphorylated serine 271 and threonine 275 demonstrate that LRRK2 phosphorylates at least one canonical activation residue of MKK7. Using an antibody specific for phosphorylated threonine 261 of MKK4, it was demonstrated that MKK4 is also phosphorylated at its canonical activation site. Western blotting showed no detectable phosphorylation of the canonical residues S209 and T211 by LRRK2 G2019S.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Densitometric analysis was performed on a Typhoon Trio Reader prior to data analysis with the Image Quant software.

Material used.Description: The structures of the LRRK2 kinase domain and PD - associated variants were modelled with the swiss - model server using the TAB1 structure (2eva) as template. For visualisation and comparison, obtained structures for LRRK2 mutants were superimposed with the wild - type model by using the DeepView Swiss - PdbViewer and rendered by the Povray ray tracing software.

Readout description.Result Description: The glycine to serine exchange in the DFG (DYG in case of LRRK2) motif of LRRK2 G2019S causes a local perturbation of the backbone structure of LRRK2. The isoleucine to threonine exchange in position 2020 (I2020T) has no predictable effect on the conformation of the backbone. The different effects of the mutations localised within the kinase domain on the local structure could explain the different activity of these LRRK2 mutants.
